historicalFigures.name: Amir Timur
historicalFigures.background: Amir Timur was a Turco-Mongol conqueror who founded the Timurid Empire. Born near Shakhrisabz, he conquered much of Central Asia, Iran, and India.
historicalFigures.legacy: Timur is the national hero of Uzbekistan. He is seen as a great statesman and builder.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His statue stands in the center of Tashkent. He is the symbol of Uzbek identity.
modernInterpretations: His brutality is downplayed in favor of his state-building.

historicalFigures.name: Al-Khwarizmi
historicalFigures.background: Al-Khwarizmi was a Persian polymath from Khiva (Khwarazm). He is the father of algebra and introduced the decimal positional number system to the Western world.
keyDecisions: Writing 'The Compendious Book on Calculation by Completion and Balancing'.
Working in the House of Wisdom in Baghdad.
historicalFigures.legacy: Al-Khwarizmi changed the world. Without him, modern computers would not exist.
quotes: When I consider what people generally want in calculating...
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His statue is in Khiva. He is a global scientific icon.
modernInterpretations: Uzbekistan claims him as a native son.

historicalFigures.name: Ulugh Beg
historicalFigures.nativeName: Mirza Muhammad Taraghay bin Shah Rukh (Ulugh Beg)
historicalFigures.background: Ulugh Beg was the grandson of Timur and the ruler of Samarkand. He was a mathematician and astronomer who built the famous Ulugh Beg Observatory.
achievements: Calculated the solar year with extreme accuracy.
challenges: Rebellion by his son (who killed him).
historicalFigures.legacy: Ulugh Beg is the martyr of science. His star catalogue was used by Oxford astronomers.
quotes: The pursuit of knowledge is the duty of every Muslim man and woman.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Samarkand is his monument. A crater on the moon is named after him.
modernInterpretations: His tragic death highlights the conflict between reason and dogma.

historicalFigures.name: Avicenna
historicalFigures.background: Avicenna was born in Afshana, near Bukhara. He is regarded as one of the most significant physicians, astronomers, thinkers and writers of the Islamic Golden Age.
historicalFigures.legacy: Avicenna is a giant of science. Bukhara is proud of him.
quotes: Medicine is the preservation of health.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a national hero in Uzbekistan (and Iran).

historicalFigures.name: Al-Biruni
historicalFigures.background: Al-Biruni was a scholar from Khwarazm. He was a physicist, mathematician, astronomer, and historian who traveled to India and wrote the first anthropological study of Hinduism.
keyDecisions: Calculating the radius of the Earth.
Traveling to India with Mahmud of Ghazni.
historicalFigures.legacy: Al-Biruni is the model of the objective scientist. He measured the earth with amazing accuracy.
quotes: I have translated into Arabic things that were known to the Indians.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a symbol of scientific inquiry.

historicalFigures.name: Imam Bukhari
historicalFigures.background: Imam Bukhari was a scholar from Bukhara who compiled the most authentic collection of Hadith (sayings of the Prophet), known as Sahih al-Bukhari.
keyDecisions: Traveling across the Islamic world to collect Hadith.
Developing a rigorous method of verification (Isnad).
Refusing to teach the governor's children privately.
achievements: Compiled the second holiest book in Islam.
historicalFigures.legacy: Bukhari defined Sunni Islam. His work is the gold standard of Hadith.
quotes: I hope to meet God with no one claiming that I have wronged him.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His mausoleum near Samarkand is a pilgrimage site.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a pillar of Islam.

historicalFigures.name: Islam Karimov
historicalFigures.background: Islam Karimov was the first President of Uzbekistan, ruling from independence in 1991 until his death in 2016. He established the modern Uzbek state.
keyDecisions: Closing the US airbase at Karshi-Khanabad.
historicalFigures.legacy: Karimov is the architect of independent Uzbekistan. He is a controversial figureâ€”stabilizer to some, dictator to others.
quotes: Uzbekistan is a state with a great future.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His statues replaced Lenin's. He defined the post-Soviet era.
primarySources: Books (Uzbekistan on the Threshold of the 21st Century).

historicalFigures.name: Ali-Shir Nava'i
historicalFigures.background: Nava'i was a poet, writer, and politician in Herat (Timurid Empire). He is the father of Chagatai (Old Uzbek) literature and proved that Turkic was a literary language.
keyDecisions: Writing in Chagatai Turkic instead of Persian.
Serving as vizier to Sultan Husayn Bayqara.
historicalFigures.legacy: Nava'i is the Shakespeare of Uzbekistan. The city of Navoi is named after him.
quotes: Words are the pearls of the ocean of thought.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is the symbol of Uzbek culture and language.
modernInterpretations: His works are the foundation of Uzbek identity.

historicalFigures.name: Abdulla Oripov
historicalFigures.background: Abdulla Oripov was a poet and politician. He wrote the lyrics to the National Anthem of Uzbekistan and was a Hero of Uzbekistan.
historicalFigures.legacy: Oripov is the voice of modern Uzbekistan. His words are sung every day.
quotes: My sunny free land, happiness and salvation to your people.
modernInterpretations: His poetry is taught in schools.

historicalFigures.name: Shavkat Mirziyoyev
historicalFigures.background: Shavkat Mirziyoyev is the current President of Uzbekistan. Since taking power in 2016, he has initiated a series of reforms to open up the country ('New Uzbekistan').
historicalFigures.legacy: Mirziyoyev is changing Uzbekistan. He is opening it to the world.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He represents hope for a better future.

historicalFigures.name: Tamar Khanum
historicalFigures.background: Tamar Khanum was a dancer and singer of Armenian origin who became a legend of Uzbek folk dance. She was the first woman to perform without a veil in Uzbekistan.
keyDecisions: Collecting folk songs from across the USSR.
historicalFigures.legacy: Tamar Khanum is the mother of Uzbek dance. She liberated women through art.
quotes: Dance is the soul of the people.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Her museum in Tashkent preserves her legacy.
modernInterpretations: Her contribution to culture is immense.

historicalFigures.name: Imam Tirmidhi
historicalFigures.nativeName: Abu Isa Muhammad ibn Isa as-Sulami at-Tirmidhi
historicalFigures.background: Imam Tirmidhi was a scholar from Termez who compiled Jami' at-Tirmidhi, one of the six major Hadith collections (Kutub al-Sittah).
historicalFigures.legacy: Tirmidhi is a pillar of Islamic scholarship. His description of the Prophet is the most detailed.
quotes: He who seeks knowledge, God will make his path to Paradise easy.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Termez is a center of pilgrimage.

historicalFigures.name: Oksana Chusovitina
historicalFigures.background: Oksana Chusovitina is a gymnast who has competed in 8 Olympic Games (a record). She competed for the USSR, CIS, Germany, and Uzbekistan.
keyDecisions: Moving to Germany to treat her son's leukemia.
historicalFigures.legacy: Chusovitina is a miracle of sport. She proves age is just a number.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She is a global fan favorite.

historicalFigures.name: Babur
historicalFigures.background: Babur was born in Andijan (Uzbekistan). He was a Timurid prince who was driven out of Central Asia and went on to found the Mughal Empire in India.
keyDecisions: Crossing the Hindu Kush to Kabul.
achievements: Writer (Baburnama is a masterpiece of Chagatai literature).
historicalFigures.legacy: Babur is a hero in Uzbekistan (birthplace) and India (empire). He is the link between the two.
quotes: There is no place like Andijan.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Andijan has a Babur park. He is a symbol of Uzbek literary heritage.

historicalFigures.name: Abdulla Qodiriy
historicalFigures.background: Abdulla Qodiriy was a writer and the founder of the Uzbek novel. He was a Jadidist reformer who was executed during Stalin's Great Purge.
historicalFigures.legacy: Qodiriy is the conscience of the nation. His novels are the foundation of modern Uzbek literature.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a national hero. His rehabilitation was a major event.

historicalFigures.name: Jalal al-Din Manguberdi
historicalFigures.background: Jalal al-Din was the last ruler of the Khwarazmian Empire. He fought a heroic but doomed war against Genghis Khan and the Mongols.
keyDecisions: Refusing to surrender to the Mongols.
Defeating the Mongols at the Battle of Parwan.
Jumping his horse into the Indus River to escape.
achievements: Inflicted a rare defeat on the Mongols.
historicalFigures.legacy: Jalal al-Din is the brave underdog. Genghis Khan admired him.
quotes: A father should have such a son.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a national hero. A massive statue was recently built in Urgench.

historicalFigures.name: Zulfiya
historicalFigures.background: Zulfiya was a prominent poet and writer. She is known for her lyrics about love, nature, and women's rights. The Zulfiya State Prize is named after her.
historicalFigures.legacy: Zulfiya is the mother of Uzbek poetry. She inspired generations of women.
quotes: I am a daughter of the East.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: The Zulfiya Prize is the highest honor for women.

historicalFigures.name: Hamid Olimjon
historicalFigures.background: Hamid Olimjon was a poet and playwright, known as the 'Poet of Happiness'. He was a key figure in Soviet Uzbek literature before his untimely death.
historicalFigures.legacy: Hamid Olimjon is the romantic hero of Uzbek literature. His partnership with Zulfiya is legendary.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Schools and streets are named after him.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a talent cut short.
